entries.title: How Tokyo Series prepared Cubs' Matthew Boyd for WBC ramp-up
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – When left-hander <b>Matthew Boyd</b> jogged out to the mound for his first spring training start, he and the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> already had a good sense of the World Baseball Classic schedule he was building up to.</p><p>“I'm not going to be doing something, in terms of between the white lines, that's different than what I've done before,” he said after throwing 1 ⅔ innings Saturday in the Cubs’ 3-2 loss to the Rangers.</p><p>Boyd praised Team USA manager <b>Mark DeRosa</b> and pitching coach <b>Andy Pettitte </b>for their communication with Cubs manager <b>Craig Counsell </b>and pitching coach <b>Tommy Hottovy</b>. The plan, Boyd said, is to use him like a starter – but that also includes piggyback setups like the Cubs used last March in Tokyo.</p><p>For the second exhibition game in Japan last spring, Boyd technically entered in relief, but that was scripted. He went through his normal start-day routine, and the Cubs had reliever <b>Daniel Palencia</b> throw ⅔ of an inning to bridge the gap between right-handed starter <b>Jameson Taillon</b> and Boyd.</p><p>In that game, on March 16, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2025/03/16/cubs-matt-boyd-has-his-best-outing-so-far-this-spring-in-exhibition-game-vs-yomiuri-giants" >Boyd showcased a jump in velocity</a>. Then he went on to have a healthy 2025 season and collect the first All-Star selection of his career.</p><p>This year's WBC is in a similar time frame, running from March 6-17.</p><p>“Very comparable," Boyd said. “That's part of the reason why it was such an easy yes to go do the WBC stuff, is this because it's very similar to what we did.”</p><p>On Saturday, Boyd struck out two of the first three batters he faced but allowed three singles in the first inning. He navigated the traffic successfully to keep the Rangers from scoring.</p><p>The second inning played out similarly, with two strikeouts, a double and a single. But Boyd allowed a run before handing the ball over with two outs.</p><p>“It was good work,” Boyd said, “Pitched with some runners on base, had to work with a guy on second, had to start some guys off with off speed and whatnot.”</p><h3><b>Long exits after collision</b></h3><p>Cubs first baseman <b>Jonathon Long </b>left the game in the fourth inning Saturday with a sprained left elbow, according to the team.</p><p>As the Rangers’ Mark Canha raced up the line to beat out a ground ball to the left side of the infield, shortstop <b>Jefferson Rojas</b>’ throw pulled Long into the basepath. Canha ran into Long’s extended glove. Long dropped the ball, and hunched over, cradling his left arm.</p><p>After an on-field examination, Long exited the field with head athletic trainer <b>Nick Frangella</b>.</p><p>Long, a non-roster invitee, was scheduled to depart Cubs camp next week to join the Chinese Taipei national team for the WBC. The injury raised questions about his availability for the tournament, but he will be re-evaluated Sunday.</p><h3><b>Ballesteros en route</b></h3><p>On top of the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/15/cubs-moises-ballesteros-likely-to-be-delayed-by-visa-issues-for-another-week" >visa issues catcher<b> Moisés Ballesteros</b> had been navigating,</a> he also went through flight delays, manager <b>Craig Counsell </b>said Saturday. Ballesteros was not in camp Saturday morning, but he had reached Houston, Texas – a promising sign in a saga that’s already delayed his arrival a week and half past his report date.</p><p>He’s not expected to appear in spring training this week, as he ramps up, but Counsell isn’t expecting the delay to impact Ballesteros’ readiness for the season.<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Chicago clergy kick off funeral services with tribute to Rev. Jesse Jackson
entries.summary: <p>Deborah Cosey-Lane couldn't help but grow emotional as she listened to clergy from across Chicago honor Rev. Jesse Jackson’s life and legacy during a heartfelt tribute Saturday morning at the headquarters of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition.</p><p>“I still have life in me because I have hope,” said Cosey-Lane, 60. “That hope was instilled because the reverend kept pouring it in when I looked like I was empty and like I was hopeless.”</p><p>Cosey-Lane was one of dozens who gathered for Rainbow PUSH’s Saturday morning forum kicking off funeral services for Jackson, who <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" >died peacefully Tuesday at the age of 84</a>.</p><p>Jackson founded the Rainbow PUSH Coalition in 1970.</p><p>Cosey-Lane met Jackson in 2016 after moving from St. Louis to Chicago and said he was instrumental in helping her “fight for herself.” She met the civil rights icon when she served as a leader in the Amalgamated Transit Union, and said he stood with them as they pushed for stronger contracts.</p><p>“And as a woman surrounded by men in leadership, he always encouraged me to not listen to the noise and always keep your faith,” Cosey-Lane said.</p><p>During the tribute, clergy from across the city gave tribute to Jackson by sharing stories of the reverend’s impact.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure Michael Eaddy of the People’s Church of the Harvest speaks during the Saturday Morning Forum at Rainbow PUSH Coalition in Kenwood.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Rev. Michael Eaddy of the People’s Church of the Harvest in East Garfield Park said Jackson inspired him to take social action.</p><p>“He inspired me in my role and as a pastor not to be confined to my church building nor to my congregants only, but to make an impact on my community and people at large,” Eaddy said.</p><p>Jackson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/10-facts-reverend-jesse-jackson-sr-chicago-connection" >rose to prominence</a> in the 1960s as a protege of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.. The reverend joined King’s cause and carried that mission to Chicago, where he championed key causes of the Civil Rights Movement, including racial equality, economic justice and human rights.</p><p>“He was my hero. He was my mentor,” Eaddy said.</p><p>Jackson’s wife, Jacqueline Jackson, and children sat in the front row during the forum while members of the community filled almost every seat in Rainbow PUSH’s South Side auditorium.</p><p>Rev. Ciera Bates-Chamberlain said the best way to honor Jackson was to continue to “keep hope alive,” the signature rallying cry of the late reverend.</p><p>“Dr. King gave us a dream and he spoke of a dream,” said Bates-Chamberlain, executive director of Live Free Illinois. “The Rev. Jackson spoke of hope.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> <bsp-carousel class="Carousel Enhancement" data-align-center> <a class="AnchorLink" impact of Rev. Jesse Jackson’s death</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Demetrice Pearson, 62, said she would “keep hope alive” by serving her community and teaching others about Jackson.</p><p>“He gave his life to helping people and serving people,” said Pearson, a member of Rainbow PUSH.</p><p>Services will continue as<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/17/what-we-know-rev-jesse-jacksons-death-services" > Jackson lies in repose</a> Thursday and Friday at Rainbow PUSH’s Kenwood headquarters at 930 E. 50th St. The services both days will start at 10 a.m.</p><p>His remains will then travel to South Carolina and Washington, D.C., from March 1 to 5.</p><p>A “People’s Celebration” in Chicago will be held at 10 a.m. March 6, at House of Hope, 752 E. 114th St. Doors open at 9 a.m.</p><p>Private homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. March 7, at Rainbow PUSH. Doors open at 8 a.m., with limited capacity.</p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: Bulls and Pistons confident that Jaden Ivey can come back from injury
entries.summary: <p>In the eyes of the Pistons and head coach J.B. Bickerstaff, it was never about if Jaden Ivey would recover from the horrific leg injury he suffered last season with Detroit, but what would be the timeline?</p><p>That question is still being asked, especially in the wake of Saturday’s news that the Bulls – Ivey’s new team thanks to the trade deadline – has shut him down for at least two weeks, concerned with how he’s looked since the deal was made.</p><p>“We expected a full recovery, but the timing you never know, which is something you can never know,” Bickerstaff said. “And then the part for him is believing and trusting in it, that happens with the injury too, especially when you’re explosive and your athleticism is so unique. You got to find that trust back in it.”</p><p>Which Ivey obviously has struggled with.</p><p>In his first 30 games pre-injury last season, Bickerstaff was watching Ivey take off, filling it up with 17.6 points per game and shooting just under 41% from three.</p><p>In his return to play this season, Detroit was giving him 17 minutes per game, he was averaging 8.2 points and shooting 37% from three with obvious drops in his play-making and explosiveness. In his first four games with the Bulls, he was getting the minutes before not playing against Toronto but looked caught in cement far too often.</p><p>There was a lot of controversy coming out of his DNP (Did Not Play) and it wasn’t helped when he declared “old J.I. is dead” afterward, but Bulls coach Billy Donovan said it was decided before that Thursday game that Ivey would sit so he could get the soreness in his knee checked out a day later.</p><p>“Certainly, it was our decision coaching-staff wise that he did not play, but I think medical guys saw that he was not moving great,” Donovan said. “They had something scheduled (Friday) to get him looked at. Clearly, we’ve got to remove some soreness to get him better, but he has to do some strengthening too with a lot of the muscles around his knee.”</p><p>That will be the immediate plan for the guard. Two weeks of strengthening and getting the leg stronger and then a re-evaluation. That doesn’t mean he’ll play again this season, but that remained the hope.</p><p>“Being able to come back from that type of injury isn’t easy,” Bickerstaff added of Ivey. “Having to do it in a situation where the team has kind of established itself when you were away, and now you’re trying to find your rhythm and not step on anyone’s toes … he wasn’t in an easy situation.”</p><p><b>A big yes</b></p><p>The Bulls also announced that Zach Collins would miss the rest of the season, as doctors have decided that his toe injury would be better served if he underwent surgery.</p><p>The often-injured big man only played 10 games this season and will be a free agent, but Donovan was all in for bringing him back.</p><p>“When a guy is in free agency there’s the financial piece of it and then there’s the part of the player, the make-up, the character,” Donovan said. “It’s hard for me knowing what a guy’s value is financially, but from my perspective as it relates to winning, when he’s out there and healthy he’s a very good player for us. From that standpoint I would hope it would all work out for him to be back here next year.”</p><p><b>Happy return</b></p><p>Eastern Conference-leading Detroit got reinforcements back against the Bulls as Jalen Duren’s two-game suspension for a Feb. 9 fight with Charlotte ended. The Pistons were still without Isaiah Stewart, who was suspended seven games for his part in the altercation.</p>
entries.author: Joe Cowley

entries.title: Cubs' Matt Shaw gets first spring training start in right field: 'A lot of fun'
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> right fielder Matt Shaw dropped-stepped to his right and then switched back to his left to camp under a fly ball.</p><p>That catch in the fourth inning was essentially the only action Shaw got in the Cubs’ 3-2 loss Saturday to the Rangers. He also picked up a ground-ball single that deflected off the end of second baseman James Triantos’ glove as he dove, and threw it in.</p><p>“Definitely a lot of fun,” Shaw said. “Listening to [center fielder Pete Crow-Armstrong,] he's guiding me along.”</p><p>Shaw’s first spring training game in the outfield wasn’t much of a test. But he’ll get more opportunities as he continues to learn the position.</p><p>“You want the tougher plays, you want the plays that don't happen as much,” manager Craig Counsell said Saturday morning. “The fly ball that goes straight up and then he catches it, and then we all [say,] ‘Oh, he can play right field,’ that tells us nothing.</p><p>“We're looking for more than that. So, you want action, you want weird plays. Those are the experiences that make you better and cause growth. And the best way to do it is just have innings out there.”</p><p>Shaw, transitioning this year from third base to a utility role, has had similar conversations with Counsell. The Cubs plan to play Shaw all over, but outfield will be a focus in spring because he’s had fewer game reps there.</p><p>“It feels like I'm kind of a kid again, running around, catching balls, diving and stuff,” Shaw said earlier this spring.</p><p>Shaw played outfield growing up, with his most recent experience coming five years ago in collegiate summer ball.</p><p>“The biggest challenge is, now that I'm going to be playing outfield, playing second, playing third, just balancing all of that,” Shaw said, “making sure I can stay healthy and stay in good shape.”</p><p>In addition to the Cubs coaching staff, left fielder Ian Happ is someone Shaw can lean on for advice as he finds that balance. Happ came up as a utility player before finding a home in the outfield.</p><p>“I'm sure he'll be <i>super</i> helpful,” Shaw said. “He already has been.”</p><p>Shaw told the story of how he reached out to Happ about whether he should get a 14 ½ -inch outfielder’s glove. The problem is, manufacturers don’t make baseball gloves that big, which Happ made sure to let him know. Anything longer than 13 inches is banned in the MLB rulebook.</p><p>“It’s the little things, you know?” Happ said.</p><p>He was joking, but the quip actually summed up Happ's real advice for juggling multiple positions. Early in his career, Happ leaned on super utility player Ben Zobrist for guidance.</p><p>“You want to go and do a bunch of things in the outfield and be the best outfitter you can be,” Happ said. “But Ben Zobrist was really good with me about, it's not necessarily about making the flashy plays, it’s about doing all the little things.”</p><p>Happ plans to have similar conversations with Shaw this spring.</p><p>Shaw can drill down on technique in practice. But there are some elements to outfield defense, like communication, situations, and navigating the wall, that can’t be fully replicated in that setting.</p><p>“True, true game speed, has to happen in-game,” Counsell said.</p><p>Once Shaw gets comfortable playing outfield in spring training, the next challenge will be playing right at Wrigley Field.</p><p>“Be careful with the wind,” right fielder Seiya Suzuki said through interpreter Edwin Stanberry when asked what his advice would be. “And be careful about the wall next to the foul line; it's dangerous.”<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Woman killed in Far South Side drive-by shooting
entries.summary: <p>A woman was killed and another wounded in an East Side neighborhood drive-by shooting early Saturday on the Far South Side.</p><p>Just after 1 a.m., both women, ages 29 and 37, were in a crowd gathered in a parking lot in the 10200 block of South Avenue J when someone opened fire from a passing blue vehicle, according to a statement from Chicago police.</p><p>The older woman was hit in the leg and the younger in the chest. They were taken to the University of Chicago Medical Center, where the 29-year-old woman later died, police said.</p><p>The 37-year-old woman was in good condition. No one was in custody as detectives investigated Saturday morning.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: 2 hospitalized in East Garfield Park apartment fire
entries.summary: <p>Two people were hospitalized after an apartment fire Saturday evening in East Garfield Park on the West Side. </p><p>The two-alarm fire broke out sometime before 6:30 p.m. in the 3400 block of West Madison Street, according to the Chicago Fire Department. </p><p>Two people were taken to area hospitals with unspecified injuries, fire officials said. </p><p>There were about 20 residents were displaced due to the fire, according to Chicago police scanner audio. </p><p>The cause of the fire wasn’t immediately known. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Police release photo of car sought in Englewood hit-and-run that seriously injured 2 girls
entries.summary: <p>Chicago police released a photo of a vehicle wanted in connection with an Englewood hit-and-run that injured a teenage girl and a 6-year-old child Friday morning on the South Side. </p><p>The vehicle was described as a white and black 2010 Lincoln MKT with llinois license plate number "FS73498," police said in a community alert. The vehicle may have damage to the front, hood and windshield and has a sticker on the left side of the rear window. </p><p>About 7:40 a.m. Friday, two girls, 15 and 6, were crossing the street in the 1700 block of West 69th Street when the vehicle struck them and did not stop, police said. </p><p>The 6-year-old girl was taken to Comer Children's Hospital in critical condition after sustaining several injuries. The teen sustained scrapes and was transported to Comer in serious condition, police said. No other injuries were reported.</p><p>Anyone who sees the vehicle is encouraged to call the Major Accidents Investigation Unit at (312) 745-4521 or submit a tip at <a class="Link" href="https://www.p3tips.com/TipForm.aspx?ID=727#" target="_blank" >CPDTIP.com</a> using reference #JK-156072. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Bears Hall of Famer Steve McMichael's widow, Misty, arrested
entries.summary: <p>Misty McMichael, who was part of the successful lobbying effort for her husband Steve’s inclusion into the Pro Football Hall of Fame before his death in April 2025, was arrested Friday and charged with domestic battery.</p><p>Will County sheriff's deputies arrested McMichael, 55, at a Frankfort home, where she was accused by an unnamed man of arguing for hours and choking him. A witness said the two had been arguing. Records indicate she was charged with misdemeanor domestic battery and physical contact. She was booked at 7:23 a.m. Friday.</p><p>Steve “Mongo” McMichael <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2025/04/23/bears-steve-mcmichael-dies-obituary-als-hall-of-fame-defensive-lineman-nfl" target="_blank" >died at 67 in April</a>, four years after being diagnosed with ALS. The defensive lineman played for the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> from 1981 to 1993 and ranks second in franchise history in sacks and third in tackles. </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-740000" name="image-740000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/41432ee/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/cee34c7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2ad204d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Misty McMichael receives the gold jacket for her husband, Steve McMichael, a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame Class of 2024, during the gold jacket dinner in Canton, Ohio, on Friday, Aug. 2, 2024. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2ad204d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3090eaa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2ad204d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Misty McMichael receives the gold jacket for her husband, Steve McMichael, a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame Class of 2024, during the gold jacket dinner in Canton, Ohio in August 2024. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Gene J. Puskar/AP Photos</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>He was inducted into the Hall of Fame in August 2024 after a successful lobbying effort. He received a gold jacket at his Homer Glen home, with fellow Hall of Famers Richard Dent, Jimbo Covert and Mike Singletary by his bedside.</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Black artists express complicated relationship with U.S. flag in show honoring nation's 250th anniversary
entries.summary: <p>Inspired by their lived experience and worldview, Black artists have reimagined one of the country’s most recognizable symbols in a new exhibition at Zhou B Art Center.</p><p>There are several depictions of the American flag at the “<a class="Link" href="https://www.pigmentintl.com/post/glory-glory-opens-this-friday-at-zhou-b-art-center-register-today" target="_blank" >Glory! Glory</a>!” show, which opened Friday. Some are missing stars, others hang upside down. One replaces the stars with tufts of cotton and the white stripes with African prints. Another, "American't" by Nnaemeka Ekwelum, is woven with plastic lacing material. It is also adorned with military dog tags bearing the names of Black children killed by police or otherwise harmed in the country.</p><p>“I like the idea of looking at this image and saying, ‘Something is off about this,’” said Ekwelum, 35, of Rogers Park. “And I think that's how we should feel when we look at the flag.”</p><p>The exhibition is on view at the Bridgeport venue Monday through Friday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., through March 20. It is part of Pigment International’s year-long programming, “America 250 — We ARE the people,” which honors the 250th anniversary of the nation's founding.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-7c0000" name="module-7c0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><b>‘Glory! Glory!’</b><br><br><b>When:</b> Through March 20<br><br><b>Where:</b> Zhou B Art Center, 1029 W. 35th St.<br><br><b>Info:</b> <a class="Link" href="https://www.pigmentintl.com/" target="_blank" >pigmentintl.com</a></div> </div><p>The Black-owned arts nonprofit is centering Black artists as part of the initiative, which is happening during a time fraught with political tension. The Trump administration is encouraging artistic celebrations of America’s 250th birthday as it dismantles civil rights protections and diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives for Black Americans. “Glory! Glory!” captures that dissonance with pieces by artists who say they are telling a full and complicated story of America.</p><p>“You can't divorce us from this history,” said Patricia Andrews-Keenan, founder of Pigment International. “I’m patriotic. Sometimes that can be a little bit of a conflict because I know the good parts of our history and I know the bad parts of our history, but it's still our history.”</p><div class="Enhancement" </div><p>The Trump administration is awarding <a class="Link" href="https://www.arts.gov/initiatives/celebrating-americas-250th-anniversary" target="_blank" >National Endowment for the Arts grants</a> for anniversary-based programming, but Pigment International was not selected as a grantee. The nonprofit was able to secure state funding from Rep. Kimberly du Buclet (D-Chicago), who chairs the Museum, Arts, Culture and Entertainment committee.</p><p>A different U.S. president is the focus of the “Glory! Glory!” exhibition’s centerpiece. Titled “44,” Robert Lewis Clark’s 11-by-8-foot mixed-media work featuring an image of Barack Obama on the American flag. The piece also includes 44 colorful wooden stars and red and white stripes painted over newspapers announcing Obama’s historic win in the 2008 presidential election.</p><p>“I wanted to inspire people to achieve their goals,” said Clark, 58, who created the piece more than a decade ago, when Obama was still in office. The Hyde Park native has since donated a print to the Obama Presidential Center.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a Stacey Abrams, who worked to expand voting rights." width="375" height="500" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c7930e3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4412x5883+0+366/resize/375x500!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa2%2F5e%2Ffcee23ec468294bcd9f1a47a3a0a%2Fblackflag-260222-003.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSI1MDBweCIgd2lkdGg9IjM3NXB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Paul Branton’s “Change Under Georgian Sky” is a portrait of former Georgia state Rep. Stacey Abrams, who worked to expand voting rights.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Arthur Maiorella/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Another politician, Stacey Abrams, is the subject of Paul Branton’s mixed-media piece, “Change Under Georgian Sky.” The portrait of the former minority leader in the Georgia House of Representatives features stars and stripes of the American flag, along with a miniature Confederate flag.</p><p>Citing Abrams' voting rights advocacy, which helped Joe Biden win Georgia in the 2020 presidential election, Branton said Abrams reminds him of Black Americans' continuous fight for justice.</p><p>“Being Black in America is basically being in love with someone that does not love you back,” said Branton, 52, of Beverly. “It’s trying to gain the attention and the admiration of someone that sometimes flirts with you and other times is very abusive to you.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/arts-and-culture/2026/02/19/chicago-diversity-survey-arts-organizations-joffrey-ballet-goodman-theatre-architecture-center" >More of Chicago’s top arts organizations agree to share diversity data following WBEZ/Sun-Times survey</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Artist Reggie McFly said he expresses that dichotomy in his piece, "In the Land of the Free." Using the flag as a backdrop, the acrylic painting reimagines "The Scourged Back," a famous Civil War-era photograph that shows the scars on the back of an enslaved man. </p><p>"I grew up listening to the national anthem and holding the flag in such high regard,” said McFly, a 37-year-old Roseland native. “But seeing the image of slavery, how could you ever disconnect the two? It was so brutal, and a lot of people lost their lives for what was supposed to be a symbol of freedom. Did that freedom ever include us?”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-580000" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Nnaemeka Ekwelum’s sculpture “American’t” is woven with plastic lacing material and adorned with military dog tags bearing the names of Black children killed by police or otherwise harmed in the country.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Arthur Maiorella/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Artist Candace Hunter of Kenwood did not spend time wrestling with the answer.</p><p>"We have never really been included in the full understanding of the word 'American' by the people who own the word," she said.</p><p>Hunter said she wanted to emphasize the contributions of African Americans with her works in the exhibit. For "Heads/Hearts/Hands," she constructed a flag from mud cloth, and sashes from fashion designer Brenda Winstead, who specializes in African prints known as Damali wear. Hunter also included organza bags of cotton, which was cultivated by enslaved Africans. Her "Birth of a New Nation" piece features an American flag flowing out of a split in a hand-carved Makonde belly mask from Africa.</p><p>"This reality we're living through really goes to show that there are those who still see us as separate from them," she said, "and yet nothing they can do can be done without us and our history in this land."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> entries.title: Horoscope for Sunday, February 22, 2026
entries.summary: <h2>Moon Alert</h2> <p>There are no restrictions to shopping or important decisions today. The moon is in Taurus.</p><h2>Aries (March 21-April 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Lucky you! This is a feel-good day and an excellent day for financial benefits. You might see ways to boost your income. You might buy something to improve your home or gift a family member. Any purchase will likely please you. Ka-ching!</p><h2>Taurus (April 20-May 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is a wonderful day because the moon is in your sign dancing with Venus and Jupiter, which makes you feel happy to be alive. In addition, relations with friends and members of groups are positive and upbeat. It's a fantastic day to schmooze. Enjoy yourself!</p><h2>Gemini (May 21-June 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> You make a fabulous impression on everyone today. Some of you might turn this advantage into a financial perk. You might get a great job offer or see how to boost your wealth in some way. You might buy something to promote your image. Looking good!</p><h2>Cancer (June 21-July 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is a fantastic day to schmooze! If you can travel, by all means, do so. Enjoy meeting new faces and seeing new places because you'll be thrilled to do something to expand your world. Romance is blessed! New love is possible. Kiss, kiss, hug, hug.</p><h2>Leo (July 23-Aug. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> People notice you today, and they will admire you because financial negotiations favor you today. Keep your pockets open because money might come to you. People will benefit you. Don't hesitate to ask for a favor. However, be patient with partners and close friends.</p><h2>Virgo (Aug. 23-Sept. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Romantic vibes are excellent for your sign today. You might meet someone different who is from another culture or different from your regular expectations. This is the classic day for romance to blossom. It's a productive day for you, but it's also friendly and social.</p><h2>Libra (Sept. 23-Oct. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is an excellent day to negotiate with others or ask for help from co-workers or health care workers. People will benefit you today, and a work-related romance might begin. Even though you will accomplish a lot today, take time out for fun.</p><h2>Scorpio (Oct. 23-Nov. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today you are blessed with a fun-loving, playful day that is friendly, romantic and stimulating. (Do get dressed.) Get out and schmooze. Meet friends, or enjoy your own solo adventure. Give yourself a mini vacation today — a treat you deserve.</p><h2>Sagittarius (Nov. 22-Dec. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Everything to do with home and family, as well as work and helping others, is beautifully favored today. The vibes are good. People are supportive. You might receive money, favors or help from someone today. In addition to this, it's a wonderfully romantic day!</p><h2>Capricorn (Dec. 22-Jan. 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Take a short trip or make an effort to learn something new today. See new places and meet new faces. New encounters could lead to fun flirtations or a mutual attraction that becomes romantic. This is also a strong day for those in sales, marketing, teaching, acting or writing because your words are gold.</p><h2>Aquarius (Jan. 20-Feb. 18)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> In addition to this being a friendly, romantic day, it's an excellent day for financial negotiations for your sign. You might boost your income, explore moneymaking ideas or be pleased with a particular purchase. Check out a better job, perhaps? All winning possibilities!</p><h2>Pisces (Feb. 19-March 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today, fair Venus is in your sign, dancing with lucky Jupiter, attracting rewards to come to you. These rewards might be personal, romantic or financial favors. Enjoy all your social interactions today because people are happy to see you!</p><h2>If today is your birthday</h2><p>First U.S. President George Washington (1732-1799) shares your birthday today. You are compassionate, clear-minded, principled, and focused. You respond to your instincts. This is a year of learning and teaching. Take time to renew your spiritual or religious beliefs. Explore meditation, prayer, or introspection as well as philosophies that give you a better sense of who you are.</p>
entries.author: Georgia Nicols

entries.title: Fire let first-half lead get away in season-opening loss
entries.summary: <p>HOUSTON — Guilherme Santos scored two goals in the second half of his MLS debut to rally the Dynamo to a 2-1 victory over the Fire in the season opener for both teams Saturday night.</p><p>Santos found the net for the first time in the 67th minute — with assists from Jack McGlynn and Ezequiel Ponce — to tie it 1-1. He scored the winner unassisted 11 minutes later off a deflection. Santos joined the Dynamo after scoring 95 goals in 429 appearances for Brazilian Série A side Santos FC.</p><p>“It's a good lesson for us," Fire coach Gregg Berhalter said. ’’We stopped playing and came out of the locker room and it was like we stayed in the locker room. Really, no movement for each other. It's like we were on autopilot. </p><p>’’If we go out and we play at half speed, we're a below-average team. When you see in the first half, when we play with real tempo, it's a really good product. But unfortunately, the second half was a very poor performance.”</p><p>Hugo Cuypers picked up where he left off last season, scoring unassisted in the 31st minute to stake the Fire to a 1-0 lead. Cuypers had 17 goals in 33 appearances last season and scored 10 times in 31 appearances in 2024 — his first season in the league.</p><p>Jonathan Bond totaled two saves for the Dynamo, while Chris Brady saved two shots for the Fire.</p><p>Before the game, Berhalter chose midfielder Anton Saletros as team captain, even though he was making his MLS debut. </p><p>“Gregg asked me a couple hours before the game if I was comfortable [being] captain, even if it was my first game,” Saletros said. ”I said I'm comfortable with the guys since the start of the season, and I was happy to get that position from him.</p><p>”We were very happy with the first half, and then second half is not up to our standards. We are very disappointed about that. So that is something we need to look through.”</p><p>The Fire play their home opener next Saturday against Montreal at Soldier Field (1:30 p.m., Apple TV, 890-AM). </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times staff and wire reports

entries.title: New-look Bulls, same results: Eight straight losses
entries.summary: <p>Former <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls" target="_blank" >Bulls</a> guard Kevin Huerter’s head had just hit the pillow, so he knew he wasn’t dreaming.</p><p>Not yet.</p><p>“There was nothing leading me up to that point to make me think that I was on the move,” Huerter said Saturday. “I got a call from [coach] Billy [Donovan] at about 1 o’clock, right before I was about to take my nap, and I hadn’t played in Miami, so I thought he was asking if I was playing that night, how I was feeling.</p><p>“And he just said, ‘Hey, just want to let you know that we just made a move to move you to Detroit.’ I was literally in my bed, like, ‘Oh, wow, OK. Let’s do it.’ ’’</p><p>It was done, and Huerter hasn’t looked back since that deadline deal.</p><p>With a 126-110 throttling of his former team at the United Center, Huerter has gone from a sinking ship to a team that has won five in a row and sits comfortably atop the East.</p><p>“That’s been great,” Huerter said, almost thankful that the Bulls did right by him on that front. “The transition, it’s always tough in season, even coming here last year, it was tough to move everything, your whole life, in about a week. But you’re going to a team like this, No. 1 in the East, and they just compete their ass off.”</p><p>The Bulls (24-33) found that out as a close game at the half turned into a laugher. The Pistons outscored the Bulls 44-26 in the third quarter.</p><p>It was the Bulls’ eighth loss in a row, and the skid isn’t likely to end soon with the Knicks coming to town Sunday, then the Hornets coming in Tuesday.</p><p>Considering the post-trade-deadline roster that Donovan has at his disposal, maybe the Bulls are designed to lose.</p><p>Josh Giddey and Tre Jones remained on minutes restrictions, Anfernee Simons left early with a sore wrist, Matas Buzelis is in a funk and Donovan still was juggling playing time for his plethora of guards.</p><p>Even with Jaden Ivey — whom Huerter was traded for — sidelined with knee woes, Donovan only found eight-plus minutes for second-year guard Rob Dillingham.</p><p>“It’s nothing [Dillingham] has not done,” Donovan said. “It’s just managing all those guards. We’re going to have a logjam there.”</p><p>But at this point, does it really matter who plays? If there’s one thing this group continues to do is show that it’s not easy to just throw a roster together and expect good things in a few weeks. Donovan has guys who are trying to understand how the player next to them functions and doing it in a new system for half the roster.</p><p>That’s why it’s easy to point to the turnover category and see another ugly number.</p><p>“Not trying to create some kind of moral victory, but I felt like it was the first game we played with the right intention,” Donovan said. “But we turned the ball over 23 times. You can’t win like that. Then we had three guys with four or five turnovers. You can’t have that.”</p><p>As for Huerter’s homecoming, he again is trying to find his way into a role after sitting for a second game, but coach J.B. Bickerstaff insisted Huerter will contribute.</p><p>Meanwhile, a bigger surprise for Huerter than not playing was what the Bulls look like after all the trades two weeks ago.</p><p>“We talked about it [as a team], and we just didn’t know,” Huerter said of the days leading up to the deadline. “We were sitting at .500 most of the year. It could have gone either way. As players, you have to expect everything, but seven or eight trades, whatever it was, I don’t know if anyone expected that.”</p>
entries.author: Joe Cowley

entries.title: Dear Abby: Unexpected guest in restroom leads to unfortunate incident
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> At a recent family gathering, my sister-in-law "Paula" asked my husband if she could use our bathroom. We have three in our home — one off the kitchen, one upstairs and one in our upstairs bedroom suite. Despite the fact that she and my husband both know of my incontinence problem, she asked him to use our bathroom "for privacy."</p><p>I had to run upstairs to use my bathroom. It was urgent. To my surprise, there she was using my bathroom. (We don't even allow our children to use this bathroom.) Because I couldn't make it to the toilet, I had a wetting accident. While I could have used any of the other bathrooms, I chose to use my own, expecting that it was vacant, knowing the other bathrooms were free for our guests.</p><p>I was extremely upset with Paula. I yelled at her, and when she saw what had happened, she was extremely apologetic. Abby, Paula knows I have bladder control issues, yet she ignored it. My husband heard the commotion and hollered at me for yelling at his sister. Did I do wrong here? He has a hard time saying no to family, but jeepers, I needed a toilet! What should I have done? — <i>GOTTA GO IN NEW JERSEY</i></p><p><b>DEAR GOTTA GO:</b> Incontinence can happen to anyone at any age. It isn't just little old ladies. Between 24% and 45% of women have reported urinary incontinence, "the problem no one wants to discuss." According to statistics from the National Institute of Health approximately 13 million individuals were affected by urinary incontinence in 2024.</p><p>You were wrong to yell at your sister-in-law, who had been granted permission to use that bathroom, but it's understandable given your distress and embarrassment. If you haven't apologized to her, you should. Frankly, the person who deserved yelling at is your husband, who may never understand the "urgency" until he experiences it himself. (Many men do!)</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> Three years ago, you printed a letter from a grandmother who was upset about having to raise her grandson because his parents lacked the desire to do so. I never forgot that letter.</p><p>Long before it was published, my husband and I gained custody of our 7-year-old grandson, "Keith." My husband and I were both retired and had been spending our winters in Florida. We gave up the Florida trips (willingly) to stay home and take care of our grandson.</p><p>Keith had always spent a lot of time with us, but he was still upset that his parents had "given him away." So, to keep busy, we joined karate, Boy Scouts, 4-H and school sports. It was one of the best times of my life. I learned new things and made new friends with grandmothers who were also raising grandchildren.</p><p>Keith graduated from high school, found a good job, bought a house and recently married. We did OK! I hope "Like a Mom in South Carolina" (Nov. 3, 2022) is doing well, too. — <i>GRATEFUL GRANDMA IN NEW YORK</i></p><p><b>DEAR GRANDMA:</b> Many grandparents today are raising their grandchildren, and many of them have success stories similar to your own. Congratulations on yours, and thank you for sharing.</p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>For an excellent guide to becoming a better conversationalist and a more sociable person, order "How to Be Popular." Send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $8 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby, Popularity Booklet, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>
entries.author: Abigail Van Buren

entries.title: State Sen. Emil Jones III survived federal charges, but now faces challengers in March primary
entries.summary: <p>Last April, it looked like Emil Jones III’s political career was over.</p><p>The South Side Democratic state senator, an officeholder since 2008, was on trial for federal charges alleging he took bribes and then lied to federal authorities.</p><p>Gov. JB Pritzker asked for his resignation. But after a mistrial, Jones, who succeeded his father, announced in December that he <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-corruption-trials/2025/12/11/illinois-sen-emil-jones-iii-strikes-deal-with-feds-to-avoid-conviction-in-bribery-case" >reached an agreement</a> with federal prosecutors that will keep him out of jail. Now he’s endorsed by large labor groups, and he’s potentially on the verge of beating two opponents in a March primary.</p><p>The power of multiple years of incumbency is hard to beat.</p><p>“Whether you have moderate or reform candidates or anti-machine candidates, it still gets down to money and organization,” said Kent Redfield, a political science professor emeritus at University of lllinois Springfield. “If people are running for legislative seats, don’t have money and don’t have organization, it’s very difficult for them to communicate.” </p><p>Newcomer Ahmed Karrar jumped into the race in January and Kenny Williams, who’s previously run for other offices, also is challenging Jones.</p><p>“I believe it is the time to have change in that position,” Williams said, referring to the seat he’s seeking.</p><p>“I’m running because working people in vulnerable communities have been neglected for some time now,” Karrar said. “I’m running to restore trust in government.”</p><p>Jones said he has competitors because of the charges he faced, which he said he can’t discuss.</p><p>“I think my record speaks for itself over the last 16 years. I have been straightforward on issues. I have been able to vote my conscience for years,” Jones said in an interview.</p><p>As for his electability, he says, “Jones is a household name in this district.” </p><p>Democratic leadership is no longer asking for his resignation.</p><p>"Senator Jones has a strong political apparatus and has demonstrated time and again he's more than capable of running a good campaign that delivers his track record and message to the voters of his district. We're keeping a close eye on that race,” said a spokesman for Illinois Senate President Don Harmon, who hasn’t formally endorsed Jones.</p><p>The only other incumbent state senator facing a challenge is on the North Side.</p><p>State Sen. Sara Feigenholtz faces a challenge from first-time candidate Nick Uniejewski in the 6th district, which includes North Side lakefront communities Lakeview, Lincoln Park and Near North.</p><p>Both candidates put transit at or near the top of their list of pressing issues. Feigenholtz touts her long record in the Illinois Senate and House, while Uniejewski is running on a message of change.</p><p>Uniejewski can't compete as a fundraiser, and has instead relied on volunteers and social media messaging, particularly on TikTok. He said he and his supporters have knocked on tens of thousands of doors. Feigenholtz had more than $1.2 million in cash on hand at the end of last year, compared with just under $34,000 for Uniejewski.</p><p>In the 9th Senate district, Patrick Hanley and Rachel Ruttenberg are competing to succeed Laura Fine, who is running in a crowded field of candidates for the 9th Congressional District seat now open with Jan Schakowsky’s decision to retire. </p><p>In the Illinois House, incumbent Rep. Jaime Andrade Jr. faces a challenge from community organizer Miguel Alvelo Rivera in the 40th District.</p><p>Rivera is endorsed by at least five elected officials, including U.S. Rep. Delia Ramirez and Alds. Rossana Rodríguez-Sánchez (33rd) and Anthony Quezada (35th). Rivera is running as a progressive outsider, while Andrade said he has a track record with voters.</p><p>In the Illinois House 8th District, Jill Bush, Shantel Franklin, John Harrell and Latonya Mitts are competing to succeed La Shawn Ford, who opted to run for the 7th Congressional District seat now open because of longtime incumbent Danny Davis' retirement.</p><p></p><p></p><p></p><p>In the 12th House District, which includes northern lakefront neighborhoods, Margaret Croke is leaving to run for state comptroller. That leaves Paul Kendrick, Litcy Kurisinkal, Karim Lakhani and Mac LeBuhn battling for the chance to serve in Springfield.</p><p>Kendrick has racked up a number of endorsements, including one from Croke. He had more than $176,000 at the end of the year. LeBuhn wasn’t far behind with more than $145,000 at the end of the year.</p><p></p><p> </p><p>After two terms in the Illinois House, Hoan Huynh jumped into the race to succeed Schakowsky, leaving a wide open race in the 13th District on the North Side. Five candidates are vying for the seat, including Adam Braun, Ridge Knapp, Sunjay Kumar, James O’Brien and Demi Palecek.</p><p>In the 34th District, Cleopatra Cowley and Aja Kearney are vying for the seat being vacated by Nick Smith, who decided not to seek re-election.</p>
entries.author: Brett Chase

entries.title: What are the advantages of filing your tax return jointly?
entries.summary: <p>It's nearly one month into tax season and some married taxpayers, especially newlyweds, may be wondering if it's worth filing a joint tax return. </p><p>Married filing jointly is one of five filing statuses taxpayers can choose from. Filing a joint tax return means a person and their spouse report their combined income, credits and deductions. This also means that both people are responsible for any tax due.</p><p>The other filing status married couples can choose when filing Form 1040 is married filing separately. Most married taxpayers choose to file a joint return since it can give them access to more tax credits and larger tax deductions.</p><p>Couples qualify for married filing jointly status as long as they were married by Dec. 31 of the tax year they're filing for.</p><h3>Who can use the married filing jointly status?</h3><p>In most cases, people who are married can use this status, but certain life circumstances may affect eligibility to file a joint tax return.</p><p><b>Divorce:</b> If a person were married, but their divorce or separation was legally finalized during the tax year, the IRS considers that person unmarried for the entire tax year, and they can’t choose married filing jointly as their filing status.</p><p><b>Annulment:</b> If a person's marriage is annulled, they must file an amended tax return for certain years affected by the annulment. But note the statute of limitations, which is three years after filing an original return or two years after a person paid the tax, whichever is later.</p><p><b>Death of a spouse:</b> If a person's spouse died during the tax year or before filing their tax return, the IRS considers them married for the whole tax year, and they can choose married filing jointly as their filing status. If a person remarries the year of their spouse's death, they can't file jointly with their deceased spouse — that person must file either jointly or separately with their new spouse.</p><p>If a spouse dies and a person has a dependent, that person might be able to file as a qualifying widower for two tax years after their spouse's death. This status allows one to reap the benefits of a higher standard deduction and a more favorable tax bracket than they would with a single filing status. Check with a tax preparer or a certified public accountant if unsure whether this applies.</p><h3>Tax credits</h3><p>One big advantage of filing a joint return is that a person may qualify for certain tax credits they wouldn’t be able to claim under the married filing separately status.</p><p>Generally, a person can’t claim the following credits using the married filing separately status:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-bce66250-fcc4-11f0-b840-f32d38e9795f"><li><b>Earned income tax credit:</b> Low-to-moderate-income taxpayers may be able to claim up to $8,046 on 2025 tax returns filed in 2026.</li><li><b>Child and dependent care credit:</b> People caring for a child under 13 or a dependent with a disability can claim up to $2,100.</li><li><b>American Opportunity tax credit:</b> Taxpayers can claim this credit for qualified education expenses, up to a maximum of $2,500.</li><li><b>Lifetime learning credit:</b> This credit covers certain education costs up to a maximum of $2,000.</li></ul><p>There are some exceptions to this rule, so check the IRS <a class="Link" href="https://www.irs.gov/credits-and-deductions" target="_blank" >website</a> about credits and deductions to see which credits one qualifies for given a specific tax situation.</p><h3>Standard deduction</h3><p>Most taxpayers can choose between itemizing and taking the standard deduction on their tax returns. </p><p>Joint filers get a higher standard deduction amount than single filers, heads of households and those married filing separately because they are allowed to combine their individual benefits.</p><p>The 2025 standard deduction for married couples filing jointly is $31,500, which applies to taxes filed in April.</p><h3>Married filing jointly versus separately</h3><p>Although it’s typically beneficial for most married couples to file a joint tax return, the IRS recommends running the numbers for both scenarios — married filing jointly and married filing separately — to see which option gives you the lower combined tax bill.</p><p>A person may consider filing separately if:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-bce68961-fcc4-11f0-b840-f32d38e9795f"><li>They have an income-based student loan repayment plan. Filing separately could lower adjusted gross income, which could lower their monthly bill. However, consider this carefully and do the math. Certain education tax credits aren’t available to married couples filing separate returns.</li><li>They have large, unreimbursed medical bills. Since one can only deduct medical bills that exceed 7.5% of adjusted gross income, a person might be able to deduct a greater amount by filing separately and reducing their adjusted gross income.</li><li>They and their spouse have a specific tax situation. If a spouse has overdue taxes that their partner doesn't want to be held liable for; if a person is in the middle of a divorce or if a person feels their spouse is being dishonest about tax information, filing separately could make sense.</li></ul>
entries.author: Bella Avila | NerdWallet

entries.title: Strategies to consider if you're looking to reduce capital gains taxes
entries.summary: <p>If a person owns investments or regularly sells assets, it's important to understand the potential tax implications.</p><p>When one sells a capital asset for a higher price than its original value, the money made on that sale is called a capital gain. And when a person sells an asset for less than its original value, the money lost is known as a capital loss.</p><p>The difference between a person's capital gains and their capital losses is their net profit. For example, if a person sold a stock for a $10,000 profit this year and sold another at a $4,000 loss, their net capital gain is $6,000.</p><p>Most items people own are considered capital assets. This can include investments such as stocks, bonds, cryptocurrency or real estate, as well as personal and tangible items like cars or boats.</p><p>Capital gains taxes are owed on profits made from the sale of assets. How much a person pays depends on what was sold, how long it was owned before selling, a person's taxable income and their filing status. Capital gains can be subject to either short-term or long-term tax rates.</p><p>Some exceptions:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-f158acd0-fcc6-11f0-af0d-45cd6ee92692"><li>High-earning individuals may also need to account for the net investment income tax, an additional 3.8% tax that can be triggered if their income exceeds a certain limit.</li><li>Long-term capital gains on so-called “collectible assets” can be taxed at a maximum of 28%. This includes items such as coins, precious metals, antiques and fine art. Short-term gains on such assets are taxed at the ordinary income tax rate</li></ul><h3>Long-term versus short-term tax</h3><p>Profits from the sale of an asset held for more than a year are subject to long-term capital gains tax. The rates are 0%, 15% or 20%, depending on taxable income and filing status. Most people pay no more than 15%, per the IRS.</p><p>Short-term capital gains tax applies to profits from the sale of an asset held for one year or less. Short-term capital gains are treated as regular income and taxed according to ordinary income tax brackets: 10%, 12%, 22%, 24%, 32%, 35% or 37%.</p><p>Capital gains taxes apply to assets that are "realized," or sold. This means that the returns on stocks, bonds or other investments purchased through and then held within a brokerage are considered unrealized and not subject to capital gains tax.</p><p>But one important caveat is investments that produce dividends. Even if a person hasn't sold a dividend stock or other dividend investment, the income they receive from the dividends may be considered a capital gain.</p><p>Assets held within tax-advantaged accounts — such as a 401(k) or an individual retirement account — aren't subject to capital gains taxes while they remain in the account. Instead, you may pay regular income taxes when it comes time to make a qualified withdrawal, depending on what type of account it is.</p><h3>Capital gains tax rate 2025</h3><p>The following rates and brackets apply to long-term capital gains on assets sold in 2025, which are reported on taxes filed in 2026.<br></p><table id="rte-f158d3e0-fcc6-11f0-af0d-45cd6ee92692"><tbody><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Tax rate</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Single</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Married filing jointly</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Married filing separately</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Head of household</td></tr><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">0%</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $48,350</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $96,700</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $48,350</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $64,750</td></tr><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">15%</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$48,351 to $533,400</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$96,701 to $600,050</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$48,350 to $300,000</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$64,751 to $566,700</td></tr><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">20%</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$533,401 or more</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$600,051 or more</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$300,001 or more</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$566,701 or more</td></tr></tbody></table><p>*Short-term capital gains are taxed as ordinary income, according to federal income tax brackets.</p><h3>Capital gains tax rate 2026</h3><p>The following rates and brackets apply to long-term capital gains on assets sold in 2026, which are reported on taxes filed by April 15, 2027, or Oct. 15, 2027, with an extension.<br></p><table id="rte-f158d3e1-fcc6-11f0-af0d-45cd6ee92692"><tbody><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Tax rate</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Single</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Married filing jointly</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Married filing separately</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">Head of household</td></tr><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">0%</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $49,450</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $98,900</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $49,450</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$0 to $66,200</td></tr><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">15%</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$49,451 to $545,500</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$98,901 to $613,700</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$49,451 to $306,850</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$66,201 to $579,600</td></tr><tr><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">20%</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$545,501 or more</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$613,701 or more</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$306,851 or more</td><td colspan="1" rowspan="1">$579,601 or more</td></tr></tbody></table><p>*Short-term capital gains are taxed as ordinary income, according to federal income tax brackets.</p><h3>How to reduce or avoid capital gains taxes</h3><p><b>Hold on</b></p><p>Whenever possible, hold an asset for longer than a year to qualify for the long-term capital gains tax rate because it's significantly lower than the short-term capital gains rate for most assets. </p><p><b>Use tax-advantaged accounts</b></p><p>These include 401(k) plans, IRAs and 529 college savings accounts, in which the investments grow tax-free or tax-deferred. That means a capital gains tax doesn't have to be paid if a person sells investments within these accounts. Roth IRAs and 529 accounts, in particular, have big tax advantages. If a person follows the account rules, they can withdraw money from those accounts tax-free. With traditional IRAs and 401(k)s, money grows tax-deferred, then your taxes are paid when distributions are taken in retirement.</p><p><b>Rebalance with dividends</b></p><p>Rather than reinvest dividends in the investment that paid them, rebalance by putting the money into underperforming investments. Typically, a person would rebalance by selling securities that are doing well and putting that money into those that are underperforming. Using dividends to invest in underperforming assets allows a person to avoid selling strong performers and thus avoid the capital gains that would come from selling securities.</p><p><b>Look into tax-loss harvesting</b></p><p>The IRS taxes net capital gain, which is simply a person's total long- or short-term capital gains (investments sold for a profit) minus the corresponding long- or short-term total capital losses (investments sold at a loss). The strategic practice of selling off specific assets at a loss to offset gains is called tax-loss harvesting. This strategy has many rules and isn't right for everyone, but it can help reduce taxes by lowering the amount of taxable gains.</p><p>If a person's net capital loss exceeds net capital gains, they can also offset ordinary income by up to $3,000, or $1,500 for those married filing separately. Any additional losses can be carried forward to future years to offset capital gains or up to $3,000 of ordinary income per year.</p><p><b>Use the home sales exclusion</b></p><p>If a person sold a house the previous year, they may be able to exclude a portion of the gains from that sale on their taxes. To qualify, a person must have owned their home and used it as your main residence for at least two years in the five-year period before they sell. They also must not have excluded another home from capital gains in the two-year period before the home sale. If a person meets those rules, they can exclude up to $250,000 in gains from a home sale if they're single, or up to $500,000 if they're married filing jointly.</p><p><b>Consider a financial adviser</b></p><p>Working with a financial adviser can help a person know how and when to take advantages of smart tax strategies in ways that are best for their specific financial situation and goals.</p>
entries.author: Sabrina Parys | NerdWallet

entries.title: What taxpayers need to know about savings plans, tax changes in 2026
entries.summary: <p>New tax deductions, such as those for tips and overtime, as well as for seniors, are some of the changes to be aware of when filing your 2025 tax return.</p><p>That’s because many of the tax deductions, and a smaller number of tax credits, are part of President Donald Trump’s so-called One Big Beautiful Bill Act.</p><p>But there are some provisions in the massive tax and spending bill that will either change or take effect this year — meaning taxpayers should prepare now ahead of filing their returns in 2027.</p><h3>State and local taxes</h3><p>The cap on deducting state and local taxes, or SALT, increased from $10,000 to $40,000 for the 2025 tax year. The deduction helps filers claim certain taxes they've already, paid like sales and property taxes.</p><p>First introduced in 2017, under Trump's first presidential term, the SALT deduction only applies if filers itemize — not those who take the standard deduction.</p><p>The SALT cap will increase annually by 1% until 2029, after which it'll revert back to its 2017 cap of $10,000, or $5,000 for married filing separately.</p><p>This year, the cap increases by $400 to $40,400, or $20,200 for married couples filing separately — amounts that would apply when filing by April 15, 2027. </p><p>The full deduction phases out for filers with modified adjusted gross income of more than $500,000, or $250,000 for those married filing jointly.
