alt="Gary Clark Jr. performs at Buddy Guy's Legends, Saturday, Feb. 21, 2026. | Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a21abd0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7660x4299+0+405/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc8%2Fa5%2Fe1cfd9404d9d9bfa19f9ec68a19a%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-14.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/80b7b09/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7660x4299+0+405/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc8%2Fa5%2Fe1cfd9404d9d9bfa19f9ec68a19a%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-14.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a21abd0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7660x4299+0+405/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc8%2Fa5%2Fe1cfd9404d9d9bfa19f9ec68a19a%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-14.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Gary Clark Jr. performs Saturday at Buddy Guy’s Legends. He’s among the latest big-name stars going back to their club roots to play shows at smaller venues. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Dates include historic and hallowed juke joints and jazz clubs like the Maple Leaf Bar in New Orleans, Hernando’s Hide-A-Way in Memphis, his beloved Antone’s in Austin and, of course, the roughly 500-person Buddy Guy’s Legends. The surprise announcement for the Chicago dates (including a second show Sunday) came a couple weeks ago and sold out within minutes.</p><p>This wasn’t Clark Jr.’s first time at Legends. That happened about two decades ago, before he was launched into the mainstream at Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival in 2010 and before the Grammy awards and the co-signs with John Legend and Foo Fighters.</p><p>But Saturday night sure looked different with packed-in tables and standing-room-only sections clogged with fans clamoring to get up close to Clark Jr.’s frenetic fret playing and rock swagger that have led to his reputation as this generation’s Hendrix.</p><p>“This is a dream for real,” the guitarist said, recalling the early days when he hallucinated about moments like these.</p><p>“Soon after I saw Buddy in Austin in this little spot called La Zona Rosa … I got his ‘Heavy Love’ record and a little bandanna with polka dots [Guy’s signature], and I put that on my wall with some thumbtacks,” he said. “Up next to that was a poster of B.B. King, The Vaughan Brothers and Michael Jackson. That was my room, that was my inspiration. … I drove up here 20-something years ago and got to play. Fast forward to now, I’m back here, baby, and it feels good.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-7d0000" name="image-7d0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/258a629/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7086x3977+0+375/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F39%2F15%2Ff8d6a9b94570877feb5205579d6c%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-17.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a4999ce/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7086x3977+0+375/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F39%2F15%2Ff8d6a9b94570877feb5205579d6c%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-17.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b20ef0e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7086x3977+0+375/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F39%2F15%2Ff8d6a9b94570877feb5205579d6c%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-17.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Gary Clark Jr. performs Saturday at Buddy Guy’s Legends. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b20ef0e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7086x3977+0+375/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F39%2F15%2Ff8d6a9b94570877feb5205579d6c%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-17.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a871c8c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7086x3977+0+375/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F39%2F15%2Ff8d6a9b94570877feb5205579d6c%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-17.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b20ef0e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7086x3977+0+375/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F39%2F15%2Ff8d6a9b94570877feb5205579d6c%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-17.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Gary Clark Jr. performs Saturday at Buddy Guy’s Legends. This wasn’t Clark Jr.’s first time at Legends. That happened about two decades ago, before he was launched into the mainstream at Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival in 2010 and before the Grammy awards and the co-signs with John Legend and Foo Fighters. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p><b></b> In a full-circle moment, Clark Jr. brought with him the trusted Ibanez Blazer guitar he profusely practiced on as a teen; it was part of an arsenal of instruments that also included the virtuoso’s brand-new signature, the Gibson Custom ES-355, released just days ago. <b></b></p><p>In the spirit of the night, he and his four-piece band stuck close to material in his canon that most resembled blues standards, from the forlorn ramble of “My Baby’s Gone” to the knee-slapping “Shake” and a cover of Magic Sam’s “Easy Baby,” all padded with winding guitar solos that made each song feel like 15 minutes long. Not that anyone was complaining.</p><p>Just one of his new tracks, “Maktub,” from his latest album, 2024’s “JPEG Raw,” made the cut. Instead, Clark Jr. mostly focused on material from a decade or more ago, including hits “Blak and Blu” and “Bright Lights” that put him back into the groove of where it all started.</p><p>To that effect, he purposely tapped one of his early allies and mentors, Austin transplant and now Chicagoan Dave Herrero, to open and join him on stage for several tracks. “I’ve known that guy since I was a teenager; I learned a lot from him,” Clark Jr. said.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2026/02/02/argentinian-blues-guitarist-ivan-singh-has-found-his-place-in-chicago" >Argentinian blues guitarist Ivan Singh has found his place in Chicago</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/movies-and-tv/2025/04/16/sinners-movie-review-michael-b-jordan-vampires-ryan-coogler" >Michael B. Jordan pulls double duty in pulsating, vein-bursting ‘Sinners’</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>In the back of the venue and at the bar were more proud onlookers from Chicago’s cool blues club — Toronzo Cannon, Ivan Singh, Wayne Baker Brooks and the godfather of them all, Buddy Guy, who Clark Jr. has continued to hold close. Everything about the night felt like the guitarist’s second-home homecoming, especially when Guy crashed the set halfway through.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-6a0000" name="image-6a0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b930888/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6113x3431+0+323/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F79%2F2d%2Fff06d0f64e16801afe6873306ba4%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-02.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8692176/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6113x3431+0+323/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F79%2F2d%2Fff06d0f64e16801afe6873306ba4%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-02.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1df257d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6113x3431+0+323/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F79%2F2d%2Fff06d0f64e16801afe6873306ba4%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-02.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Buddy Guy joins guitarist Gary Clark Jr. on stage for a performance at Buddy Guy's Legends, Saturday, Feb. 21, 2026. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1df257d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6113x3431+0+323/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F79%2F2d%2Fff06d0f64e16801afe6873306ba4%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-02.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f59f93f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6113x3431+0+323/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F79%2F2d%2Fff06d0f64e16801afe6873306ba4%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-02.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1df257d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6113x3431+0+323/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F79%2F2d%2Fff06d0f64e16801afe6873306ba4%2Fgaryclarkjr-260223-02.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Buddy Guy joins Gary Clark Jr. on stage Saturday. He performed a medley of “Five Long Years,” “Love Her with a Feeling,” “King Bee” and a cover of B.B. King’s “Downhearted.”</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“They said we want you to go up there and f--- up a song,” Guy joked as he took the stage, using Clark Jr. and his band as his own personal backup for a medley of “Five Long Years,” “Love Her with a Feeling,” “King Bee” and a cover of B.B. King’s “Downhearted.”</p><p>“I like this band,” Guy chided as he bid Clark Jr. to play him a solo. Of course, the guitarist happily obliged.</p><p><b></b> At nearly 90 years old, Guy still loves his craft and feels more relevant than ever with his recent Grammy win for “Ain’t Done with the Blues,” recognition as Variety<i> </i>magazine’s Living Legend and a cameo in the movie “Sinners,” which is up for a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/movies-and-tv/2026/01/22/sinners-makes-history-setting-oscars-nomination-record" >record-breaking 16 Oscar nominations</a>. <b></b> Appearing with Clark Jr. this night felt like a proverbial passing of the torch. As the club’s announcer, Johnny, astutely shared, “The blues is alive and well … this is history in the making tonight.”</p><p>Clark Jr. felt it, too. “Well s--- … I’m satisfied. It could be over now,” he joked after the impromptu collaboratio. “We had a plan, and we’ve gone off course,” he admitted, “but we have found ourselves in some place unimaginable and incredible.”</p><p><b></b></p><h3>Gary Clark Jr. Set List for Feb. 21 show at Buddy Guy’s Legends</h3><p>Maktub<br>Ain’t Messin’ Round<br>When My Train Pulls In<br>The Healing<br>My Baby’s Gone<br>Don’t Owe You a Thang<br>Feed The Babies<br>Five Long Years (Buddy Guy song, with Buddy Guy)<br>Love Her with a Feeling (Buddy Guy and Junior Wells song, with Buddy Guy)<br>King Bee (Buddy Guy song, with Buddy Guy)<br>Downhearted (B.B. King song, with Buddy Guy)<br>Hoochie Coochie Man (Muddy Waters cover, with Buddy Guy)<br>Shake (with Dave Herrero)<br>Easy Baby (Magic Sam cover, with Dave Herrero)<br>Blak and Blu (with Dave Herrero)<br>Bright Lights (with Dave Herrero)</p>
entries.author: Selena Fragassi

entries.title: Blackhawks' Colton Dach hoping to earn more ice time after rejuvenating break
entries.summary: <p>The moment <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" target="_blank" >Blackhawks</a> forward Colton Dach felt the familiar sheets of his bed at his family home during the Olympic break, he crashed.</p><p>"I was sleeping by 10, and I woke up at 10 [a.m.]," Dach said. "I was just like, 'Ahh.' You don't have a schedule the next day. You don't have to go ‘boom, boom, boom.’ You wake up and just sit there and find something to do."</p><p>By the time Dach returned to Chicago a week ago for a long stretch of practices, he felt rejuvenated.</p><p>"I texted [Landon Slaggert] and was like, 'I'm so excited to come to the rink now,'" he added. "It's good to get that feeling back. It kind of feels like training camp — even the weather was a little bit nicer. You're driving in with your windows down. You get that energy. Hopefully we can take that into the last [25] games here and really showcase ourselves and make a push."</p><p>Dach could personally use a strong final push, because his job security has dwindled since a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/09/28/blackhawks-colton-dach-nhl-roster-physicality-hits-oliver-moore" target="_blank" >promising start</a> and even more forward competition is currently en route to the NHL.</p><p>Much focus will be on the Hawks’ pending unrestricted free agents leading up to the March 6 <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2026/02/21/blackhawks-nhl-trade-deadline-preview-connor-murphy-jason-dickinson-ilya-mikheyev" target="_blank" >trade deadline</a>, but after that, focus will shift toward the pending restricted free agents who will need new contracts after the season. </p><p>That’s a small group headlined by Connor Bedard that also includes Dach, Kevin Korchinski, Ethan Del Mastro and Drew Commesso.</p><p>Dach is the only one of those four prospects who has yet broken into the NHL full-time, but it’s up to him to maintain firm grip of his current role. That will heavily influence his contract negotiations.</p><p>He has recorded nine points (three goals and six assists) and 184 hits in 52 games this season. That’s more than twice as many hits as any other Hawk, and coach Jeff Blashill praised him Friday for his consistent physicality.</p><p>Other parts of his game haven’t been as consistent, however, which has caused his ice time to slip from 14 minutes per game in October to 11:09 since. He was a healthy scratch several times in January.</p><p>"After Christmas, my game dipped a little bit, and that's where I need to showcase that consistency factor," Dach said. "That's something I've been working on the last three years, trying to be consistent, and every year it's gotten a lot better.</p><p>"[I’m trying to be] more responsible in their eyes, trying to be trustworthy, trying to get a little more ice time."</p><p>So far during this mini February camp, Dach has skated on the fourth line with Slaggert and Nick Foligno, but that’s with Teuvo Teravainen absent at the Olympics. Teravainen's return (with a bronze medal in hand) will force somebody out. It's worth noting Dach remains waivers-exempt until next season while Slaggert will require waivers after making one more NHL appearance.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Alex Vlasic was wearing his Team USA helmet around before Blackhawks practice to gloat.<br><br>Then one of the equipment guys decided to make Colton Dach wear it.<br><br>There wasn’t a bet, though. Vlasic: “Because I didn’t want to have to do something if we lost.”<br> <a href="https://t.co/10lCTWhXum">pic.twitter.com/10lCTWhXum</a></p>— Ben Pope (@BenPopeCST) <a href="https://twitter.com/BenPopeCST/status/2025640412849770821?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 22, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>Blashill has encouraged Dach to move his feet more, and they recently had a meeting in which Blashill showed him specific areas where that would help him.</p><p>"When he skates, he’s a lot to handle, and we just have to get him skating on a more consistent basis," Blashill said in January. "If we can get him [in the] habit of moving onto the puck, making sure he’s skating when he gets the puck and skating to disrupt when he doesn’t get the puck, it’ll make him that much better of a player."</p><p>The Hawks’ newly altered defensive system, which requires wingers (like Dach) to more aggressively pressure opponents on the boards, might force him to do exactly that.</p><p>"If a guy is running up the wall...I can force him to make a play, put them under pressure," Dach said. "Pucks are going to come loose, and hopefully my feet are pointed up the ice and I can get going."</p>
entries.author: Ben Pope

entries.title: Illinois' budget blues were around long before Trump's cuts
entries.summary: <p>Gov. JB Pritzker just put a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/springfield/2026/02/18/jb-pritzker-budget-proposal-state-of-state-social-media-tax" >$56 billion</a> general fund budget proposal for fiscal year 2027 on the table. Of that amount, roughly $16.2 billion, or 29%, covers “hard costs” the state must pay, because they’re either required by law, such as debt service owed to bondholders, or contractual obligations.</p><p>That leaves $39.8 billion to fund services for the year, with 95% of those service expenditures targeted to the four core areas of education (pre-K, K-12 and higher education), health care (primarily Medicaid coverage for low-income families), social services and public safety.</p><p>As governors are wont to do, Pritzker made a point of emphasizing his fiscal accomplishments during the budget speech. Usually, when elected officials crow about their performance, there’s a fair bit of spin that has to be unwound before the reality of that performance is laid bare. Not so in this case. The data shows Pritzker has been a truly responsible fiscal steward.</p><p>Under Pritzker’s watch, the state has garnered <a class="Link" href="https://gov-pritzker-newsroom.prezly.com/illinois-achieves-10th-rating-upgrade-since-governor-pritzker-took-office" target="_blank" >10 consecutive credit upgrades</a>, which happen to be the first such upgrades for Illinois in the last 25 years. That’s a far cry from the eight <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2021/7/2/22561261/illinois-credit-downgrade-history-springfield-rich-miller" >downgrades Illinois suffered</a> under his predecessor, Gov. Bruce Rauner, who left Pritzker an $8 billion backlog of unpaid bills and next to nothing in Illinois’ rainy day fund. Pritzker completely eliminated that unpaid bill backlog, built the rainy day fund up to $2.4 billion while also paying off some $12 billion in debt.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-0d0000" name="module-0d0000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>But Pritzker’s budget address wasn’t all sunshine and lollipops. Categorizing FY 2027 as a “challenging” budget year, Pritzker proposed increasing general fund service expenditures by less than “one-half of 1 percent” over last year, that is if you ignore inflation.</p><p>But just like in the private sector, inflation drives up the cost of funding services in the public sector. After adjusting for inflation, proposed FY 2027 spending for the four core services is actually about 1% less than this year. Illinois’ fiscal condition is so “challenging” that Pritzker had to include $649 million in new revenue-generating initiatives in his budget proposal, just to limit the year-to-year real spending cut to 1 percentage point.</p><p>The governor laid much blame for Illinois’ FY 2027 fiscal challenges at the feet of President Donald Trump, claiming the tax cuts, Medicaid cuts, and Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP, cuts in the president’s “Big Beautiful Bill” will cost Illinois some<a class="Link" href="https://gov-pritzker-newsroom.prezly.com/gov-pritzker-proposes-eighth-balanced-budget" target="_blank" > $8.4 billion</a> to backfill over the next five years. And that estimate actually understates the long-term problem. Beginning in FY 2028 and continuing thereafter, the average annual cost to Illinois of fully compensating for all the damage done in Trump’s "Big Beautiful Bill" hits $4.43 billion.</p><p>While it’s appropriate to blame Trump for fiscal difficulties his ill-conceived policies create for all 50 states, in Illinois, Trump’s shenanigans have simply exacerbated a longstanding “structural deficit” that’s historically plagued the general fund. Illinois’ structural deficit exists because state tax policy is so flawed it doesn’t align with the modern economy. Hence, general fund revenue consistently grows at a slower rate than needed to cover inflation-adjusted increases in the cost of maintaining service levels over time. Worse, Illinois unfairly overtaxes low- and middle-income folks, while under-taxing the wealthy.</p><p>And contrary to common belief, overspending hasn’t caused Illinois’ structural deficit. In fact, after inflation, spending on the four core services is 13% less under Pritzker’s FY 2027 proposed budget than it actually was under Republican Gov. George Ryan back in FY 2000. That’s problematic because current spending levels aren’t even adequate to cover existing needs. While space doesn’t permit listing all public services the data show are inadequately funded, two of the more compelling examples involve education.</p><p>Start with K-12. The good news is Illinois ties school funding to paying for educational practices the evidence shows actually improve student achievement. The bad news is K-12 funding is $3.2 billion less than what the evidence indicates is needed to provide every child a quality education.</p><p>Then there’s higher education. After inflation, proposed general fund spending for higher education in FY 2027 is 43% less than actual spending was in FY 2000. This disinvestment makes no sense. Why? Well, in 1979, a full-time worker with a bachelor’s degree earned 38% more than a high school grad. By 2020, that wage gap more than doubled to 85%. Underfunding higher deducation puts Illinois at a competitive disadvantage in the modern economy.</p><p>Fortunately, there are textbook approaches to tax reform that’d simultaneously eliminate the structural deficit and tax people more fairly. But for decades state politicians have avoided fixing tax policy, choosing instead to demagogue the issue. That scores political points but doesn’t solve problems.</p><p>Bottom line: Illinois will never overcome its structural fiscal challenges and invest adequately in core public services, until elected officials put politics aside and fix tax policy to work in the modern economy.</p><p><i>Ralph Martire is </i><a class="Link" href="https://www.ctbaonline.org/about/ctba-staff" target="_blank" ><i>executive director</i></a><i> of the </i><a class="Link" href="https://www.ctbaonline.org/" target="_blank" ><i>Center for Tax and Budget Accountability</i></a><i>, a nonpartisan fiscal policy think tank, and the </i><a class="Link" href="https://www.roosevelt.edu/profile/rmartire" target="_blank" ><i>Arthur Rubloff Professor of Public Policy</i></a><i> at Roosevelt University.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-e80000" name="module-e80000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Ralph Martire

entries.title: 'El Mencho,' who led Jalisco New Generation Cartel that supplies U.S. cocaine trade, killed by Mexican army
entries.summary: <p>MEXICO CITY — The Mexican army killed the leader of the<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2018/8/15/18338774/with-el-chapo-in-jail-dea-and-mexico-focus-on-other-cartels-with-chicago-ties" > Jalisco New Generation Cartel,</a> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2018/10/16/18452115/feds-up-reward-for-kingpin-el-mencho-to-10m-get-win-in-cartel-cash-case-here" >Nemesio Rubén Oseguera Cervantes, known as “El Mencho,”</a> in an operation Sunday.</p><p>The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration views the Jalisco cartel as being as powerful as the Sinaloa cartel that came to prominence under its leader <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/el-chapo" >Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman Loera,</a> with a presence in all 50 U.S. states, where it distributes tons of drugs. </p><p>It is one of the main suppliers of cocaine to Chicago and the rest of the United States, according to the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/08/08/sinaloa-el-chapo-secret-cocaine-dea-lab-tests-flood-cocaine-cartels" >DEA,</a> and, like the Sinaloa cartel, makes billions from the production of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2023/3/15/23641813/dea-sheila-lyons-fentanyl-sinaloa-cartel-jalisco-new-generation-drug-enforcement-administration" >fentanyl</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/2/24/23610152/methamphetamine-meth-fatal-overdoses-deaths-cook-county-drug-seizures-dea-adderall" >methamphetamines</a>.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2020/3/11/21175651/jalisco-new-generation-drug-cartel-chicago" >50 in Illinois, nearby among 600 busted in crackdown on drug cartel supplying Chicago</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2020/4/10/21213581/jalisco-new-generation-cartel-luis-alderete-el-mencho-grenade-launchers-el-chapo-sinaloa" >Busted in Chicago suburbs, top aide to cartel boss ‘El Mencho’ wanted grenade launchers: prosecutors</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2018/10/16/18452115/feds-up-reward-for-kingpin-el-mencho-to-10m-get-win-in-cartel-cash-case-here" >Feds up reward for kingpin ‘El Mencho’ to $10M; get win in cartel cash case here</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>A Mexican federal official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said El Mencho's killing happened during a military operation in the western state of Jalisco and followed several hours of roadblocks with burning vehicles in Jalisco and other states. Such tactics are commonly used by Mexico's drug cartels to block military operations.</p><p>Videos circulating on social media showed plumes of smoke billowing over Puerto Vallarta, a major city in Jalisco, and sprinting through the airport of the state's capital in panic.</p><p>The U.S. State Department had offered a reward of up to $15 million for information leading to the arrest of El Mencho. </p><p>The Jalisco New Generation Cartel is one of the most powerful and fasted growing criminal organizations in Mexico.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-0a0000" name="image-0a0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ce99b49/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffb%2F16%2F80cb8602b63f7206c1ec54582f8c%2Fmerlin-102181582.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f463eb9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffb%2F16%2F80cb8602b63f7206c1ec54582f8c%2Fmerlin-102181582.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dffa8be/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffb%2F16%2F80cb8602b63f7206c1ec54582f8c%2Fmerlin-102181582.jpg" entries.title: Kyle Williams' Super 25 high school girls basketball rankings for Feb. 22, 2026
entries.summary: <p>The first week of the IHSA playoffs has already shown just how unpredictable this postseason will be.</p><p>Defending IHSA Class 4A champion Kenwood and DePaul Prep were knocked out early by Hinsdale Central and Lane, respectively. Kenwood's 50-49 loss was surprising. The Broncos were impressive in their CPS city championship win over Butler, with a stifling defense that performed well at the right time.</p><p>Hinsdale Central has had a roller-coaster of a season but found its stride in January, winning nine of 10 games — that one loss came by two points to No. 15 Glenbard West. But in February, the Red Devils lost 48-32 to Downers Grove North and 58-33 to Evanston. But they're now riding high on their momentum from beating Kenwood to another showdown with Downers Grove North. Tuesday's game will be the third matchup between the two teams this season and the Trojans are 2-0.</p><p>The Red Devils have one of the area's best seniors in Katherine Skinner. She scored 25 in the regional championship — Hinsdale Central's first since 2015 — against the Broncos. She's one of the best defenders in the area and will need to deliver a strong performance to keep the Red Devils' season going.</p><p>Sophomore guard Riley Orozco is an impressive floor spacer who was a West Suburban Silver All-Conference selection.</p><p><b>Lane's rise</b></p><p>Lane is better than its record indicates. I saw the Champions play in the city playoffs against Young and came away impressed despite Lane's loss. The Champions are at their worst when they turn the ball over, which leads to them losing the possession game.</p><p>But when they keep the turnovers low, the Champions are a formidable team. Sophomore Anais Harris is supremely impressive as a rebounder. She creates so many second-chance opportunities just off her hustle and activity around the rim. She's averaging 7.6 rebounds per game and is an impressive finisher in the paint. Sophomore Vega Ransom-Marks is an impressive scorer with a nice touch on her floaters and is adept at creating scoring chances for her teammates with her passing vision. Ransom-Marks is averaging 13.5 points on 42% shooting.</p><p>Lane has a chance to advance to the sectional championship if it can beat a balanced Maine South team on Tuesday.</p><p><b>Redhawks-Warriors part three</b></p><p>Naperville Central is 2-0 against Waubonsie Valley this season. For the Redhawks to keep their season going, they'll have to beat the Warriors a third time, which is hard to do. There's a familiarity between the teams after playing each other numerous times.</p><p>What's intriguing about this matchup is that each team boasts marquee players: Naperville Central senior forward Trinity Jones (Clemson) and Danyella Mporokoso (Illinois State). Mporokoso averaged 28.6 points this season and is one of the area’s best scorers. But Jones, a McDonald’s All-American, can also score with the best of them while being a deterrent on the defensive end.</p><p>The game will likely be decided by how well the Warriors can defend the Redhawks’ forwards — Jones and junior 6-4 forward Annabelle Kritzer.</p><p><b>The Super 25, with record and last week’s ranking:</b></p><p><b>1. Nazareth (30-3) 1</b></p><p>Plays St. Ignatius Tuesday in sectional semifinals</p><p><b>2. Loyola Academy (30-2) 2</b></p><p>Plays Evanston Tuesday in sectional semifinal</p><p><b>3. Waubonsie Valley (30-3) 4</b></p><p>Plays Naperville Central Tuesday in sectional semifinal</p><p><b>4. Benet (26-4) 5</b></p><p>Plays Bolingbrook Tuesday in sectional semifinal</p><p><b>5. Mother McAuley (24-6) 6</b></p><p>Plays Homewood-Flossmoor Tuesday in sectional semifinal at McAuley</p><p><b>6. Downers Grove North (29-2) 7</b></p><p>Plays Hinsdale Central Tuesday in sectional semifinal at Hinsdale Central</p><p><b>7. Naperville Central (26-6) 8</b></p><p>Plays Waubonsie Valley for the third time Tuesday</p><p><b>8. Fremd (25-6) 9</b></p><p>Plays Hersey Tuesday in sectional semifinal at Schaumbaurg</p><p><b>9. Providence (29-4) 10</b></p><p>Plays T-F North Tuesday in sectional semifinal at Hilcrest</p><p><b>10. Kenwood (25-7) 3</b></p><p>Lost to Hinsdale Central in regional championship</p><p><b>11. entries.author: Kyle Williams

entries.title: Two teens charged with murder during carjacking spree across North, South sides
entries.summary: <p>Two teenagers were charged over the weekend for fatally shooting two men during a carjacking spree earlier this month that spanned the North and South sides, Chicago police said.</p><p>Marquese Hill, 18, and a 17-year-old boy were charged with several felonies, including first-degree murder and aggravated vehicular hijacking with a weapon, according to police. Hill faces additional charges for aggravated battery of a police officer and aggravated vehicular hijacking of a handicapped person. Police did not name the 17-year-old because he is underage.</p><p>Darwin Tirado, 22, and Damon Kellum, 45, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/12/murderslinked" target="_blank" >were killed about an hour apart</a> in the Feb. 11 attacks.</p><p>Tirado was sitting in a parked car with a friend just before 4 a.m. in the 700 block of West Waveland Avenue in the Lakeview neighborhood. The two had left a nearby tavern when Hill and the 17-year-old allegedly attacked them, police said.</p><p>Tirado was fatally shot, and his friend, a 38-year-old man, was punched in the face. The friend got out of the Hyundai Sonata and Hill and the teenager fled in the car, according to police.</p><p>Less than an hour later and 12 miles south in Oakland, Kellum was in his car in the 3700 block of South Lake Park Avenue when Hill and the 17-year-old allegedly fatally shot him, police said. They got into his Nissan Altima and drove to a gas station in the 4200 block of South Wentworth Avenue in Fuller Park. Tirado’s car was found near where Kellum was killed, according to police.</p><p>At the gas station, police say Hill and the teenager tried to steal a 70-year-old man’s car at gunpoint. But when they attempted to get away in the car, the driver was able to flee with his keys, according to police.</p><p>They got back in the stolen Nissan and drove to the 8600 block of South Lafayette Avenue in Chatham around 5 a.m. They approached a 38-year-old man sitting in traffic in a Chevy Malibu. They forced him out of the car at gunpoint and fled.</p><p>When police tried arresting him Feb. 19, Hill, who was using crutches, hit an officer with the crutches. He also faces charges for a carjacking from Jan. 10 in the 7500 block of N. Claremont Avenue in West Rogers Park.</p><p>The teenager was arrested later that afternoon.</p><p>The two made their first court appearances Saturday and were ordered held until trial.</p>
entries.author: Kaitlin Washburn

entries.title: Munetaka Murakami will play more first base before leaving for Japan
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz — Munetaka Murakami has handled first base flawlessly in his first two games for the White Sox, and manager Will Venable confirmed his left-handed-hitting slugger will receive more playing time at his new position before departing Friday for Japan to play in the World Baseball Classic.</p><p>Murakami, who played five innings at first Sunday against the Brewers, will start Monday as the designated hitter against the Rockies before returning to first on Wednesday and Thursday.</p><p>“It's still a process, but I'm getting used to little by little, so I'm getting there,” Murakami said after making an unassisted putout on a slow grounder by Jesus Made in the the third and a catch of a foul pop by Jeferson Quero against the dugout railing in the fifth.</p><p>“Once I got to it, there was the fence right over here, so I was pretty surprised, but I'm really glad that I got it,” Murakami said.</p><p>In his first game for the Sox at first on Friday, Murakami handled a grounder and flipped to pitcher Tyler Schweitzer at first to complete a smooth putout.</p><p>Murakami, 26, played third base for most of eight seasons in Yakult, but first base will be his primary position with the Sox. It doesn’t hurt that he played 266 games at first, but only eight last season for Yakult.</p><p>Murakami was positioned one step in front of the first base bag while facing the mound when holding runners, then pivoting and squared toward home plate as the pitch was being delivered.</p><p>Venable wanted to give Murakami wanted to give ample time at first before he leaves for Japan, where he’s expected to play third.</p><p>“If I'm feeling healthy and good, I'll try to play every single game that's out there,” said Murakami, who went 0-for-2 with a strikeout Sunday.</p><h3>Homework on ABS</h3><p>The Sox will be somewhat selective in using the Automated Ball-Strike System (ABS) they used successfully on Saturday.</p><p>The Sox have studied data from the 2025 season at the Triple-A level, examining what type of pitches and locations have worked, as well as the best time to issue a challenge.</p><p>“Guys have an understanding, and we want to use this time in camp to fine-tune our strategy,” Venable said.</p><p>Catcher Edgar Quero said bench coach Walker McKinven has reviewed the system with the catchers, adding, “if we 100 percent (believe) it’s going to be a strike, we can challenge.” But in most cases, they might save challenges for the last inning in key situations.</p><p>Each team has two challenges, which can be retained if the call is overturned.</p><h3>Boxed in</h3><p>Venable has received mix messages from umpires regarding enforcement of the coaches’ box, in which umpires must insure that coaches are “within their designated areas” while the pitcher is on the rubber.</p><p>“Our understanding now is that it’s really going to be the depth or the proximity to the foul line and to home plate, where then you have space to go back away from the foul line or away from home plate,” Venable said. “That’s what we’re expecting.”</p><p>The rule puts third base coach Justin Jirschele in a tough spot with a runner at second base, Venable said.</p><h3>Sox 5, Brewers 2</h3><p>• Dru Baker, Sam Antonacci and Drew Romo collected RBI hits during a three-run sixth that helped overcome a 2-1 deficit. Austin Hays, battling for playing time at the corner outfield spots, led off the second with a double and scored on Curtis Mead’s single.</p><p>• Catcher Korey Lee, who is out of options and could be the odd man out in a two-catcher alignment, nailed two would-be base stealers. Antonacci, however, bobbled a potential double-play grounder at second in the fifth.</p><p>• Mike Vasil, battling for a spot in the back end of the rotation, threw 18 pitches to the first three batters and was disappointed that he fell constantly behind in counts. He left after 26 pitches with two out in the first, but returned in the second for 16 more pitches before being pulled in favor of Luke Bell with two out.</p><p>On deck: Sox at Rockies, 2:10 p.m. Monday, Scottsdale, Shane Smith vs. Michael Lorenzen.<br></p>
entries.author: Mark Gonzales

entries.title: White Sox prospect Sam Antonacci showing how he can 'create havoc'
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — In a sport increasingly obsessed with power, load management and top prospects, Sam Antonacci is creating his own path to the majors.</p><p>Antonacci earned a spot on the White Sox’s spring training roster despite only 1 1/2 seasons of professional baseball as a fifth-round pick.</p><p>That’s because Antonacci has displayed multiple intangibles that could help supplement a lineup full of sluggers in the future.</p><p>“He is a gamer,” said Ryan Fuller, the Sox’s director of hitting. “The best part with him is he is coachable. He wants to know what he needs to get better at. So we see his incredible on base skills, his ability to take a walk, get hit by a pitch, hit a single, steal second base, create havoc.”</p><p>Those traits were on display in 519 plate appearances at Class-A Winston-Salem and Double-A Birmingham, in which Antonacci posted a .433 on-base percentage, an 86.8 percent contact rate and a 13.3 percent walk rate.</p><p>His on-base percentage was aided by getting hit by pitches 35 times, but that didn’t slow him down as he stole 48 bases.</p><p>More impressive was that the left-handed hitting Antonacci, 23, showed no signs of slowing down. He led the Arizona Fall League with 28 hits and 24 runs in addition to batting .378 in 74 at-bats, and MLB Pipeline ranked him as the 11th top prospect in the organization despite not being picked until the fifth round in 2024.</p><p>“Honestly, I kind of have an unorthodox way of training, especially hitting in the offseason,” Antonacci said. “I like to hit quite a bit, and I like to hit when I'm tired, too. So whether that's like 300 to 500 swings in a day, and I'm tired on half of those.</p><p>“A lot of people think like when you're tired, you're going to develop bad habits, but my thought process is when I'm swinging tired in the cage with my dad, it's I'm preparing to play in October and those those cold nights in the playoffs. So I'm going to be tired during the end, so I might as well practice tired.”</p><p>Antonacci also hit three home runs in the AFL - two shy of his regular season total - and hit a homer in Friday’s exhibition opener against the Cubs. The Sox will be patient about letting Antonacci create more power without compromising his hitting and on-base skills.</p><p>“We have three main skills here, our decisions, our contact, and then your damage,” Fuller said. “Sam is unbelievable with his decisions and contact, and as he's getting stronger, as he's swinging our weighted bats in our bat speed program, those are naturally going to come, and he's already showing that.</p><p>“But you never want to take away those inherent skills that Sammy has that are elite.”</p><p>The Sox have a glut of young infielders, including incumbent second baseman Chase Meidroth. Antonacci has played third and shortstop as well as second.</p><p>“I got drafted to to help the White Sox, whatever they need,” said Antonacci, who transferred from Heartland Community College in Springfield to Coastal Carolina after the 2023 season.</p><p>“… Honestly, when I was in college, I was just hoping to get drafted. Obviously, I was trying to help Coastal Carolina win at that time. But once that ended, I was just hoping to be able to continue to play baseball.</p><p>“And at the end of the day, all the numbers, all the rankings, how much money you make, goes out the door, and once you cross those white lines, I don't know any of that. I don't know how much money you make or what draft pick you were. We're on the same field, so I got a good chance to win.”<br></p>
entries.author: Mark Gonzales

entries.title: Archdiocese has 'no plan' to reopen 6 Catholic schools after families push to keep them open
entries.summary: <p>Parents and community members continued their fight Sunday to keep St. Hubert Catholic School in Hoffman Estates open a month after learning it was set to close at the end of the school year.</p><p>About two dozen parents, students and staff appealed to Cardinal Blase Cupich by demonstrating in front of Holy Name Cathedral after attending Mass there Sunday morning. They then marched several blocks to the archdiocese office in the Gold Coast.</p><p>“When the schools are in trouble, the archdiocese is silent,” said Angel Garcia, whose child attends the school, at a news conference. “This falls on Cardinal Cupich.”</p><p>Hours later, the Archdiocese of Chicago Office of Catholic Schools said the decision was made “with heavy hearts after months of discussions” but maintained that enrollment was too low and deficits too high.</p><p>"There are no plans to revisit those decisions," a spokesperson with the Archdiocese of Chicago Office of Catholic Schools told the Sun-Times. “Many people have worked hard at each school to raise money and try to boost enrollment. We recognize and value those efforts but, in the end, the schools were not able to close the gaps, and they are no longer sustainable.”</p><p>Michelle Flowers, a mother of four students who went to the school and is herself an alumna, said it was “deeply troubling” and hoped the archdiocese would reconsider the move.</p><p>“This is the first we’ve heard from them,” Flowers said of the archdiocese's statement to the Sun-Times. “They have not given us any meaningful opportunity to communicate with them. … Catholic schools are not meant to operate as balance sheets. If the archdiocese isn’t even willing to come to the table, that represents an abandonment of a mission.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-2c0000" name="image-2c0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" Cardinal Blase Cupich to halt the closing of their school.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>In January, the archdiocese announced its intention to close the 65-year-old St. Hubert at the end of this school year. It was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2026/01/26/archdiocese-catholic-school-closing-jerome-bruno-richard-francis-borgia-stanislaus-kostka" target="_blank" ><u>among six area Catholic grade schools</u></a><u> </u>— ncluding four in the city of Chicago — the archdiocese decided to close, citing declining enrollment and ongoing financial losses.</p><p>The other suburban school is Our Lady of Humility in Beach Park, and the four Chicago schools are:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-956094e2-1032-11f1-8c88-037bc6605a5a"><li>St. Bruno and St. Richard, 5025 S. Kenneth Ave. in Archer Heights</li><li>St. Jerome, 2801 S. Princeton Ave. in Armour Square</li><li>St. Francis Borgia, 3535 N. Panama Ave. in Dunning</li><li>St. Stanislaus Kostka, 1255 N. Noble St. in West Town</li></ul><p>The six schools slated for closure had declining enrollment over the last decade, although their enrollment has been relatively stable in the last five years, according to filings with the Illinois State Board of Education. St. Hubert and Our Lady of Humility had a little more than 200 students for the 2024-2025 school year, and the rest of the schools fell below 200 students.</p><div class="Enhancement" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>St. Hubert Catholic School parent Jillian Bernas Garcia (right) marches Downtown alongside parents from Our Lady of Humility School to call on Cardinal Blase Cupich to halt the closing of their schools.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Parents from St. Hubert began a formal process to challenge the closure at the end of January, just days after they were informed the school would shutter later this year. The 30-day window for a response closes in early March, and if they still have yet to hear from Cupich, they say they will appeal to the Vatican.</p><p>Parents at the school had begun to rally to save it, operating under the name the Save St. Hubert Coalition and commissioning an <a class="Link" href="https://img1.wsimg.com/blobby/go/3b43c279-356e-48de-a967-284cd93d4d3e/downloads/9740eae4-30fb-4819-bd85-326d8efdc2b0/Redacted%20-%20Financial%20Analysis%20St.%20Hubert%20Catho.pdf?ver=1770946307149" target="_blank" ><u>independent financial analysis</u></a>, which they said found the school can operate in its current state for five more years, or be “cash-flow positive” in two years with a 10% reduction in spending — such as by cutting two full-time positions and making the gym teacher part time. The report found staffing costs were the biggest driver of overhead.</p><p>They blame tuition increases and the elimination of tuition discounts, which allowed students to attend even if they could pay half of the $8,000 annual cost of attending the school, which the group said prevented nearly 50 students from enrolling at the school last year. They also allege $500,000 was taken out of a fund dedicated to infrastructure at the school to pay off parish debts.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>St. Hubert Catholic School parent Jillian Bernas Garcia speaks outside the Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago offices in the Loop calling for Archbishop Cardinal Cupich to halt the closing of the school, Sunday, Feb. 22, 2026.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Jillian Bernas Garcia, a parent of two children at the school, said when she and others reached out to parents at the other closing schools, they saw a pattern of lack of transparency. She called for “true cooperation between the hierarchy and faithful” and said the group wants a dialogue on how to keep the school open.</p><p>“This should definitely not have resulted in the decision to close the school,” Bernas Garcia said. “The deficit was set at this high, insurmountable goal. I think it discourages people from supporting the school, and I think that was done intentionally.”</p><p>The Archdiocese of Chicago Office of Catholic Schools wouldn’t answer questions about the allegations made by parents.</p><p>A <a class="Link" href="https://www.gofundme.com/f/save-st-hubert-catholic-school-a-community-united" target="_blank" ><u>GoFundMe</u></a> to help fund efforts to save the school has already raised more than $20,000 of its $500,000 goal — the deficit number diocese leaders gave as the reason why the school must close.</p><p>The closure would force parents to choose between public schools and the next nearest comparable Catholic schools in neighboring suburbs like Roselle or Arlington Heights, Bernas Garcia said.</p><p><i>Contributing: David Struett</i></p>
entries.author: Violet Miller

entries.title: Visa issues resolved, Cubs catcher Moises Ballesteros reports to camp
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> catcher Moisés Ballesteros originally targeted mid-January to leave Venezuela and head stateside, giving him a long runway up to spring training.</p><p>Instead, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/15/cubs-moises-ballesteros-likely-to-be-delayed-by-visa-issues-for-another-week" >a visa and travel saga</a> kept Ballasteros in a holding pattern until this weekend. He finally joined Cubs camp Sunday, about a week and a half after the report date for Cubs pitchers and catchers.</p><p>“Those were things that were out of the control of the team, out of my control,” Ballesteros said Sunday through team interpreter Fredy Quevedo Jr. “Thankfully, I'm here. And I'm ready to give it my absolute best.”</p><p>This was the first time Ballesteros had to renew his visa in five years in the Cubs organization, he said. And when the United States captured Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro in early January, Ballesteros was anxious about what that would mean for travel outside of his home country.</p><p>That didn’t end up being the issue. But the visa process dragged on. And Ballesteros spent the past week and a half in Colombia, waiting for it to be resolved.</p><p>“It was unfortunate how it all goes down,” manager Criag Counsell said. “He had to be patient, I think that's the biggest thing. And so now we’ve got to be a little patient here and give him some time to just run around for a bunch of days, swing the bat casually, and gradually increase the workload and swing volume.</p><p>“But he’s here. And it’s Feb. 22. So, we’ve got plenty of time.”</p><p>Ballesteros said he had access to a nearby stadium near his hotel in Colombia, where he used the weightroom and field. He was able to still throw and swing a bat in that time.</p><p>“Not at the intensity that it happens here,” Counsell said. “So we have to understand that. And he's not in his home country. It’s one thing being stuck at home waiting to come here, and then there's being stuck somewhere else and having to come here.”</p><p>For the first time in his young career, Ballesteros enters spring training with a strong shot at making the Opening Day roster.</p><p>He debuted last season and really found a rhythm in a September stint, when he recorded a .999 OPS in 46 plate appearances, mostly as a designated hitter.</p><p>“He showed what got him to the big-leagues,” manager Craig Counsell said. “That’s not always easy to do in a smaller sample and right off the bat. … He's a gifted hitter, and the ball goes hard all over the field. Kind of no rhyme or reason, but that's just a sign of a good hitter. ... He's a guy that can handle a lot of pitches, a lot of different pitch types”</p><p>Ballesteros didn’t play in the field until the final series of the season. He played first base late in a blowout win against the Cardinals. And then after the Cubs had secured home-field advantage for the NL wild-card round, he started behind the plate in their final regular-season game.</p><p>Honing the defensive side of Ballesteros’ game will be the next major step in the 22-year-old’s development.</p><p>“I want to give it my 100%,” he said, “and show that I can also be behind the plate.”</p><p>That first week and a half of catching bullpens and live batting practice sessions would have been helpful. Because of the delay, Ballesteros likely won’t appear in Cubs spring training games this week. But Counsell said he expects Ballesteros to catch a lot over the next month and take some reps at first base.</p><p>"I was anxious,” Ballesteros said of the extended visa process. “But I'm happy to be here, be here with my team.”<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: DePaul basketball still has demons, as latest dispiriting loss shows
entries.summary: <p>Keep these "Three Points" in mind with two weeks to go in <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/college-sports" target="_blank" >college basketball</a>’s regular season:</p><p><b>1. DePaul still has demons</b></p><p>Just when you thought DePaul was getting something going, another bad-looking, gut-punch loss arrived. This one was 71-68 against Big East last-place contender Providence at Wintrust Arena on a night when the Blue Demons — in a not-bad sixth place out of 11 teams — were trying to get to seven conference wins for the first time since 2018-19 on the way, hopefully, to more than that for the first time since 2006-07.</p><p>But no. A 12-for-24 disaster from the foul line got in the way. Veteran guard Layden Blocker missed four freebies — the last one intentionally — in the final 20 seconds. There’s always another way to lose, it seems.</p><p>The Friars sat on a plane for six hours Friday and never got the bird off the ground, then didn’t finally get to O’Hare until five hours before game time on Saturday. Advantage, DePaul? It sure looked like it when Blocker lobbed to CJ Gunn for a dunk and a six-point lead midway through the second half. But the Demons — who lead the nation in lob dunks, believe it or not — coughed up all their momentum and the game. Maybe next year/decade/century?</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">LOB CITYYYYYY<br><br>13:44 2H | DePaul 49, Providence 43 <a href="https://t.co/6EZWxhJcT9">pic.twitter.com/6EZWxhJcT9</a></p>— DePaul Basketball (@DePaulHoops) <a href="https://twitter.com/DePaulHoops/status/2025400160814014971?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 22, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p><b>2. Not great, Michigan</b></p><p>Had the Wolverines beaten Duke in D.C., we’d be asking where this 15-1 Big Ten team ranks among the best in the conference since its last national title (Michigan State in 2000). OK, fine, we’re asking anyway. It could go up or down from here, but right now we’d (very) tentatively slot them fifth or sixth since those Spartans. Yes, the Sun-Times made a top 10 list a couple of years back — Illinois’ 2004-05 and Ohio State’s 2006-07 teams were 1-2 — and will have to revisit it if the Wolverines finish 19-1, which would be an amazing feat.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/college-sports/2026/02/22/illinois-fighting-illini-college-basketball-ucla-donovan-dent-march-madness-big-ten" target="_blank" >Illini ‘O’ is golden, but their ‘D’ keeps foldin’. Is it a fatal flaw?</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p><b>3. February madness</b></p><p>Houston plays at Kansas on Monday. St. John’s and UConn tangle on Wednesday. Michigan State and Purdue go at it on Thursday, followed by Michigan at Illinois on Friday. Yes, it’s that time of year. Enjoy it. Or you can follow along as the Bulls tank like nobody’s watching. It’s your party, people.</p>
entries.author: Steve Greenberg
